content.question:
For parts of the free-response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate. 

<math alttext="2 H 2 O 2, aqueous, reacts to produce 2 H 2 O, liquid, plus O 2, gas " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>→</mo><mn>2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>O</mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>l</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>

Hydrogen peroxide, <math alttext="H 2 O 2 " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, decomposes according to the equation above. This reaction is thermodynamically favorable at room temperature.

A. A particulate representation of the reactants is shown below in the box on the left. In the box below on the right, draw the particulate representation of all the molecules that would be produced from these four reactant molecules.

frqParts.text:
For parts of the free-response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate. 

<math alttext="2 H 2 O 2, aqueous, reacts to produce 2 H 2 O, liquid, plus O 2, gas " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>→</mo><mn>2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>O</mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>l</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>

Hydrogen peroxide, <math alttext="H 2 O 2 " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, decomposes according to the equation above. This reaction is thermodynamically favorable at room temperature.

A. A particulate representation of the reactants is shown below in the box on the left. In the box below on the right, draw the particulate representation of all the molecules that would be produced from these four reactant molecules.

B. Shown below is a potential energy diagram for the uncatalyzed decomposition of <math alttext="H 2 O 2, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mtext>(</mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mtext>)</mtext></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>.

i. According to the diagram, is the decomposition reaction exothermic or endothermic? Justify your answer.

ii. Manganese dioxide, <math alttext="M n O 2, solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Mn</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, is an insoluble substance that acts as a catalyst for the decomposition reaction. On the diagram above, draw a curve to represent the reaction as it occurs in the presence of <math alttext="M n O 2, solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Mn</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>.

A student investigates the decomposition reaction in the laboratory. The student prepares two small beakers, adding <math alttext="20.0 milliliters" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>20.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>mL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of <math alttext="9.77 molar H 2 O 2, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>9.77</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mi>M</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> to each one. Each beaker is placed on an electronic balance. The student adds <math alttext="0.10 gram" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.10</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>g</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of <math alttext="M n O 2, solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Mn</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> to the second beaker and records the mass of each beaker and its contents at 10-second intervals for one minute. The beakers and the data are shown below.

Time (seconds)
 Mass of Beaker 1 <math alttext="plus" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="H 2 O 2, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mtext>(</mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mtext>)</mtext></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> (grams)
 Mass of Beaker 2 <math alttext="plus" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="H 2 O 2, aqueous, plus M n O 2, solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mtext>Mn</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mtext>(</mtext><mi>s</mi><mtext>)</mtext></mrow></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> (grams)

<math alttext="0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="43.09" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>43.09</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="43.19" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>43.19</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="10" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="43.09" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>43.09</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="43.06" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>43.06</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="20" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>20</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="43.09" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>43.09</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="42.94" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>42.94</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="30" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>30</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="43.09" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>43.09</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="42.83" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>42.83</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="40" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>40</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="43.09" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>43.09</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="42.73" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>42.73</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="50" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>50</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="43.09" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>43.09</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="42.65" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>42.65</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="60" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>60</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="43.09" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>43.09</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="42.58" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>42.58</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>

C. For beaker 2 during the 60-second period, calculate the following.

i. The number of moles of <math alttext="O 2 gas" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msub><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>(</mtext><mi>g</mi><mtext>)</mtext></mrow></math> that was produced

ii. The mass of <math alttext="H 2 O 2, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mtext>(</mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mtext>)</mtext></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> that decomposed

D. The student continues the experiment for an additional minute. For beaker 2, will the mass of <math alttext="H 2 O 2, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mtext>(</mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mtext>)</mtext></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> consumed during the second minute be greater than, less than, or equal to the mass of <math alttext="H 2 O 2, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mtext>(</mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mtext>)</mtext></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> consumed during the first minute? Explain your answer referring to the data in the table.
E. Based on the data, the student claims that the catalyzed reaction has zeroth-order kinetics. Do you agree with the student’s claim? Justify your answer.

F. A second student did the experiment using larger volumes of <math alttext="9.77 molar H 2 O 2, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>9.77</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mi>M</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> . The student noticed that the reaction in beaker 2 proceeded extremely rapidly, causing some of the liquid to splash out of the beaker onto the lab table. The student claims that as a result of the loss of the liquid from the beaker, the calculated number of moles of <math alttext="O 2, gas" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mtext>(</mtext><mi>g</mi><mtext>)</mtext></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> produced is greater than the actual number of moles of <math alttext="O 2, gas" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mtext>(</mtext><mi>g</mi><mtext>)</mtext></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> produced during the first 60 seconds. Do you agree with the student? Justify your answer.

G. The hydrogen peroxide used in this experiment can be prepared by the reaction of solid ammonium peroxydisulfate, <math alttext="open parenthesis, N H 4, close parenthesis, sub 2, end sub, S 2 O 8 " overflow="scroll"><mrow><msub><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtext>(N</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>)</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>S</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>8</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></math>, with water. The products are hydrogen peroxide <math alttext="H 2 O 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> and ammonium bisulfate <math alttext="N H 4 H S O 4" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mstyle><mrow><mtext>N</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>HS</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></math>. Write the balanced equation for the reaction.

skill.text: 3.A: Represent chemical phenomena using appropriate graphing techniques, including correct scale and units.
